chapter.title: Introduction
chapter.para: This document will outline how to set up your development environment in order to build Fabric Engine Core under Mac OS X, Linux, and Windows. The builds under all three systems are generally done from the command prompt, using Mingw32 under Windows for more UNIX-like functionality. The Fabric Engine Core is used by all Fabric applications whether in the browser or in a language binding module.

Fabric supports the following platforms:
Windows: Vista or Windows 7.
Mac OS X: 10.6 (Snow Leopard) or above
Linux: Tested on Ubuntu 10.04 and above (32-bit or 64-bit). Should work with any modern distro.

section.title: Prerequisites
section.para: Before getting started you will need several packages installed in order to be able to retrieve and compile the Fabric source code. Packages vary depending on build operating system.

section.title: Windows
Install software
section.para: The following software is required to build Fabric on Windows:

listitem.para: Microsoft Visual C++ Express. Use standard settings.

section.para: You'll also need to add the python and python/scripts folders to your PATH environment variable. To do so click on the Windows Menu, choose “Control Panel”. Now click on “System and Security”, followed by “System”. Finally, click on “Advanced System Settings”, followed by the “Environment Variables” button. In the top list, create a new variable called “PATH” and choose “c:\Python27;c:\Python27\Scripts” as its value. If the variable “PATH” already exists, append “;c:\Python27;c:\Python27\Scripts” to its value.
The Fabric Engine source code is hosted in a GitHub repositroy, which uses SSH for security. You will need to set up Git and SSH on your windows machine to be able to clone the repository.

section.title: Install Git and Configure SSH
section.para: Install Git for Windows and (optionally) set up your github ssh key by following the instructions found here: Set Up Git
If you want the system to remember your git passphrase, you can follow the instructions found here: Why git can't remember my passphrase under Windows

section.title: Install Xcode
section.para: Install the latest version of Xcode (4.1 as of this writing). This should automatically get you the git binary so you can check out the source.

section.title: Linux
section.para: A few packages are necessary to build under Linux, namely the compiler, bison, and scons. Assuming you are running Ubuntu, you may run:

para.command: sudo apt-get install build-essential scons bison

section.para: If you are running a different distribution use your appropriate package manager to install the required application.

section.title: Install Git
section.para: Follow the instructions on GitHub for setting up Git on Linux. linux-set-up-git

section.title: Build Folder
section.para:
You first need to choose a directory where the Fabric source code will live. Assuming that myuser is your local username, the recommended paths are:
Windows: c:\Users\myuser\Fabric
Mac OS X: /Users/myuser/Fabric
Linux: /home/myuser/Fabric
You will then need to set an environment variable called FABRIC_CORE_PATH that points to this newly-created directory. Under Mac OS X and Linux, this can be done by running:
You may also want to add this to your ~/.bash_profile or ~/.profile file.

Under Windows you'll want to set it as a permanent environment variable by going to Control Panel -> System -> Advanced System Settings -> Advanced -> Environment Variables. You can create a new variable named FABRIC_CORE_PATH and set it to c:\Users\myuser\Fabric (or whatever directory you chose).

section.title: Install Pre-built Third-Party Binaries
section.para: Certain additional custom-compiled binaries are needed to compile Fabric. These are platform-specific and available from the PublicDev github page.

listitem.para: From the downloads page for the PublicDev repository, download the latest set of pre-built third-party binaries for you platform.

note.para: Important note: If you are building on Windows, you will need to copy two resource headers from your Visual Studio Professional install into Fabric before compiling. In your VS install path, under VC\atlmfc\include\ there should be files named afxres.h and winres.h, these will need to be copied to your $FABRIC_CORE_PATH\Native\Clients\NPAPI\Windows\ folder.
